item.properties: Kawad-kawaran is a tropical and subtropical creeping grass with slender, branched, prostrate, usually widely creeping stems, rooting at the nodes and forming matted tufts, sending up erect, slender, flowering branches, 8 to 20 centimeters high. Leaves are 1.5 to 3 centimeters long. Spikes, numbering 3 to 4, are 2 to 5 centimeters long, narrowly linear, spreading, green to purplish. Spikelets are imbricated, about 1.5 millimeters long.
item.usage: Decoction of the entire plant used as diuretic.||In India, crushed leaves used as styptic in minor wounds to stop bleeding.||Decoction of root used as diuretic in dropsy. and syphilis.||In Sind, the roots are used as a substitute for sarsaparilla.||Infusion of root to stop bleeding from piles.||Juice of plant applied to fresh cuts and wounds.||Paste of plant applied to forehead in headaches.||Used internally for epilepsy, hysteria, bleeding in dysentery, hemorrhoids, hematuria, menorrhagia, syphilis, prostatitis.||Used for toothaches and amibiosis.||Mixed with clove (Syzygium aromaticum) used as anthelmintic.||Folk remedy for cancer, epilepsy, cough, dysentery, warts, snakebites.||In Morocco, used in treatment of kidney stones.
